author: langsgalgenrad
body:
I have been looking around on the web and could not find a solution or a topic about it. My apologies if there is somewhere. When I use the write-error and redirect the output to a file it will result in weird symbols in the file. The other ones like write-warning or write-output work fine. 

## Steps to reproduce

```
Write-Output "Lalala" 1> C:\Temp\test.txt 
Write-Error "This is a test" 2>&1 >> C:\Temp\test.txt 
Write-Warning "Test Testt" 3>&1 >> C:\Temp\test.txt 
Write-Information "Information Information" 6>&1 >> C:\Temp\test.txt 
```

## Expected behavior

**Output in the file:**

Lalala
C:\Users\MoonChild\Documents\huh.ps1 : This is a test
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [Write-Error], WriteErrorException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.WriteErrorException,huh.ps1
Test Testt
Information Information


## Actual behavior

**Output in the file:**

Lalala
[91mWrite-Error: [91mThis is a test[0m
Test Testt
Information Information


## Environment data

PSVersion                      7.1.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}       
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

comments.author: zett42
comments.body:
This seems to be caused by `$ErrorView = 'ConciseView'`, which is the default. 
See https://stackoverflow.com/a/65861562/7571258

The actual bug appears to be the output of ANSI escape codes, even when redirected to a file. If not a bug, it is at least inconsistent in regard to other `$ErrorView` modes, which also color the console output, but do not emit ANSI escape codes when redirected to a file.

Note that `Out-File` exhibits the same behaviour as the redirection operators `>` and `>>` in this regard:

    $ErrorView = 'ConciseView'
    Write-Error "This is a test" 2>&1 | Out-File test.txt

Output:

    [91mWrite-Error: [91mThis is a test[0m

comments.author: doctordns
comments.body: @RipTornMist Thanks for that interesting comment.  Which version of Powershell are you using, and on which OS?

comments.author: mklement0
comments.body: Great sleuthing, @zett42. Note that `>` / `>>` in essence call `Out-File` / `Out-File -Append` behind the scenes, so the behavior will always be the same.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body:
/cc @SteveL-MSFT
The [`$PSStyle` work](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/13758) provides a workaround for the "PowerShell error stream redirection" scenraio, which requires you to set `$PSStyle.OutputRendering = "Host"`. The default `$PSStyle.OutputRendering` value is `Automatic`, which keeps the current behavior that people here observed. The `$PSStyle` work is available in PowerShell v7.2.0-preview.2.

But setting `$PSStyle.OutputRendering` won't chanage the behavior of `Write-Error "This is a test" 2>&1 | Out-File test.txt`, I believe, because the trick was done in the redirection code.

title: Write-error gives weird symbols when using >> to redirect it to a file.
